title: This Oscars Moonlight f***-up is a triumph for people who love cinema | Metro News
text:
But in actual fact, it was more than that. 
It was a rare moment of Hollywood schadenfreude, and one of unparalleled beauty. 
The mask slipped and the triviality of the Academy Awards was exposed for all to see. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
And the ultimate victory of the real winner, Barry Jenkins’ Moonlight, was all the more delectable because everyone who had come to grudgingly accept that La La Land would win was proved wrong. When you win the oscar right after you lost the oscar #lalaland #Moonlight #Oscars #BestPicture pic.twitter.com/MCnucgD5BD 
— rhea lahiri (@RheaForReal) February 27, 2017 To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
Telling a story about love that’s worthy of attention rather than merely making gestures at one, Moonlight is a miles better movie than La La Land and its other six (former) rivals. 
But it had only a little star power backing it, and La La Land — no doubt bolstered by a huge incentive campaign budget — seemed to be a shoe-in because Whiplash mastermind Damien Chazelle had won Best Director. 
Not only that, but everyone had been saying that the Academy would favour La La Land because of its focus on old Hollywood and the fact it celebrates the ‘dreamers’ who create stories (spoiler: it doesn’t). To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
In that respect, the awkward Beatty cock-up seems to symbolise the old Hollywood dying off and giving way to greater variety and less circle-jerking. 
It’s also now crystal clear that ‘Oscars buzz’, a golden mist that hovered around La La Land for months on end, is really just bulls***. The Moonlight team belatedly accept their award (Picture: Kevin Winter/Getty Images) 
It’s a shame that no celebrity panellist acknowledged, during the rather flimsy TV commentary on Sky, that Moonlight was the most deserving winner, obvious though that was. 
Egg is firmly on their faces now. 
So thank you, Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway. 
You’ve inadvertently robbed Chazelle of yet another Oscar, while rescuing what could have been a sad 89th Academy Awards, with Moonlight only taking Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor for Mahershala Ali. 
La La Land may have scooped six Oscars to go with all their freshly-minted Box Office dough, but they didn’t get that Best Picture cherry on top. And that’s a positive omen. 
Maybe next year the Academy can nominate a wider variety of films so hype doesn’t determine what people see at the cinema. Well, we can dream, can’t we, Damien? What is Moonlight about? Everything you need to know about the Best Picture Oscar winner 
Mahershala Ali and Alex R Hibbert star in Moonlight (Picture: REX/Shutterstock) 
What’s the plot? 
Moonlight is a coming-of-age film , charting the life of Chiron across three defining chapters of his life – starting out as a young black man growing up in turbulent Miami, it follows his ongoing struggles with his sexuality and unstable family life. 
As we follow his life through his teenage years and into manhood – the film becomes a much broader inspection into identity as a whole. 
Is it any good? 
In our review , we described the film as ‘extremely moving’ which ‘speaks of the struggles of black men in marginalised communities, of the push and pull of nature versus nurture, and finding yourself – no matter how long it takes.’ 
Can I see a trailer? 
Yes, yes you can. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
Who’s in it? 
Main character Chiron is played by three different actors over the course of the film: Alex R. Hibbert plays his younger self, Ashton Sanders plays his teenage years and Trevante Rhodes plays Chiron in his adult prime. 
Playing his close friend Kevin is another batch of three actors, including Jharrel Jerome, Jaden Piner and Andre Holland. 
The film also boasts an excellent supporting cast, including Mahershala Ali (Best Supporting Actor for his role as drug dealer Juan), Janelle Monae as Teresa and Naomie Harris as Paula. 
Who’s behind the camera? 
Barry Jenkins has directed the film and also written the screenplay. 
Where can I catch it? 
Moonlight is currently showing in UK cinemas now.
